collectionHeaderMetadata.description: Fighting a Stage-4 Carcinoma Diagnosis by Ted Rheingold
collectionHeaderMetadata.title: Season of the Witch

header.description: Fighting a Stage-4 Carcinoma Diagnosis by Ted Rheingold
header.title: Season of the Witch

paragraphs.name: b37a
paragraphs.text: I often pondered the philosophy of cancer because it’s hard to make sense of it. What’s the evolutionary benefit of killing your host when that kills you too? Why does cancer win to die? I was surprised to find so few results on Google. I asked my sister who has studied cancer for 20 years and she said it would be a good post for my blog. Cancer isn’t a virus or bateria. It’s a mutation. A mutation that happens with great regularity amongst some but not all mammals and it mutates in one of a recurring common or rare manners. What is cancer’s purpose. Is it to cull the herd? Is cancer non-evolutionary (i.e. not created by natural forces)? Is cancer still evolving? Is it’s end goal to become transferable from person to person? Tasmanian Devil populations have become decimated by a transferrable facial tumor disease. Are human cancers mutating in half of all humans for the chance to find the variant that leads to transferability? Will cancer jump the transferability firewall? What is the philosophy of cancer?

paragraphs.name: 776e
paragraphs.text: I’ve gained some powerful emotional powers (super powers) in what I’ve been calling my second life. Most all my deep-set hangups died with my first life. A number (but not all) of my grudges, entitled expectations, self-assumed responsibilities, judgements are simply gone. I have no FOMO. There isn’t an event I’ve heard of since I’ve recovered that I wish I would have been at. I’m simply content to be alive and living my. I have no bucket list. Life is the bucket.

There isn’t an event I’ve heard of since I’ve recovered that I wish I would have been at. I’m simply content to be alive and living my life. I have no bucket list. Life is the bucket.

paragraphs.name: b163
paragraphs.text: I never know what to say, except if you need anything at any time, even if it’s just a novel face for a coffee, let me know. It’s brilliant to have you doing so well and your writing is, as ever, extraordinary, honest and moving.

content.subtitle: Thank you. This was meant for me.

979aea87d3c3.title: We we diagnosed the same week last year.

paragraphs.name: 175a
paragraphs.text: We we diagnosed the same week last year. My son and I driving in an in between world space of dying tears and living wills from upstate NY to UPenn hospital for diagnostic confirmation and hopefully surgery. And I too am alive, through my son now knows where my ashes would have and may still be strewn. A ‘nuanced’ tumor was no match for the magically…

14cda9438027.title: I’m on a train in Sydney, Australia trying to process your journey.

paragraphs.name: 6c49
paragraphs.text: I’m on a train in Sydney, Australia trying to process your journey. Ted you’ve just reminded me and us of how resilient humanity can be. From one stranger to another at opposite ends of our planet, thank you!

paragraphs.name: b742
paragraphs.text: My story is very different and yet similar. I came down with acute heart failure caused by pneumonia. I felt weak but that was it. My heart efficiency (ejection factor) was approx. 14% (measured twice by different operators and machines). I asked the cardiologist what I had to do to get…
So beautiful. so real.So true.

virtuals.subtitle: I also appreciate your analysis of the evolutionary purpose of cancer. Before cancer I had always believed in a causal relationship: you…

paragraphs.name: 366e
paragraphs.text: Thank you for this. I agree that “life is the bucket.” I am a uterine cancer survivor. My up-close and personal appointment with mortality turned my carefully nursed decades-old grudges into will-o-the-wisps that disappeared in a flash. What a relief to find that those thoughts and feelings don’t matter in the grand scheme of my life!

content.subtitle: That’s one of the best things you can ever do for another person, thank you for writing it.

paragraphs.name: de6c
paragraphs.text: When I was diagnosed with leukemia and laying in the hospital bed undergoing chemo, I realized I was thrust into another world, a rather large place most people prefer to ignore. The land of the sick.

paragraphs.name: ae2f
paragraphs.text: I appreciate your very well written description of that place. That place where desperate hope and easy fear tries to survive…

paragraphs.name: bb09
paragraphs.text: It most certainly is

492079752716.title: May the rest of your life be long and happy!

paragraphs.name: 825f
paragraphs.text: May the rest of your life be long and happy! A stunningly courageous and beautifully written piece from a good man.

paragraphs.name: 872e
paragraphs.text: Could I just add, though, the hope that the drug that helped you so much can be made available to all who need it rather than only those who can pay its full cost? Should relative poverty be a death sentence?
